passage_text: Corporate Resolution Needs for an LLC. A limited liability company, also called an LLC, is a business entity type that enjoys certain legal and tax benefits modeled after a corporation, but it is not an actual corporation. An LLC has management flexibility that a corporation does not have.

A Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) combines the benefits of the traditional partnership in respect of legal affairs and tax treatment together with that of limited liability to protect partners’ personal assets.

A Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) and a limited liability company (L.L.C. or LLC) differ in their legal liabilities and business obligations and have some pros and cons when compared to other business organization structures like corporations, partnerships, and limited partnerships.
Firms must complete the Registered Limited Liability Partnership Registration (Secretary of State Form LLP-1) and submit it to the Secretary of State along with a filing fee.

A change of name does not occur when a company decides to change its status, such as from a public company to a private limited company. For example, J Smith Limited to J Smith PLC. This type of change is called re-registration and should not be confused with a standard change of name.

**Note** : Any existing Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) will need to file the particulars of designated partners/ partners with the registrar at the time of their appointment along with any subsequent changes in the particulars of partner(s) thereafter.

Signed resolutions need to be kept with the LLC's business records. They remain on file indefinitely to provide proof of formal decision-making in case a dispute arises that ends up in court and members need to prove that business actions were authorized by a vote.
